##Wang Guangfa, a member of the Health Commission's Expert Group, was discharged from the hospital and answered eight questions

Wechat, bingdianweekly

Features, China Youth Daily's in depth reporting brand. We believe that news has more than one day of life.

![img](data:image/jpeg;base64,)
On January 30, the head of the Department of respiratory and Critical Care Medicine, Peking University First Hospital, who had contracted pneumonia from COVID-19, was discharged from Ditan Hospital in Beijing. He is the fifth person in Beijing to have been cured of pneumonia after being discharged from the COVID-19. Xinhua News Agency (photo by Ren Chao)

Interview Arrangement, Qin Zhenzi

Editor, Zhang Guo

Peking University First Hospital, a member of the Expert Group and Director of the Department of respiratory and critical care medicine, travelled to Wuhan with the Expert Group from January 8 to 15.

Until Jan. 11, the disease was defined as a "viral pneumonia of unknown origin" until the pathogen was tentatively identified as a COVID-19. On January 10, Wang Guangfa in an interview with the media, said the overall epidemic "can be controlled. ". A few days after returning to Beijing from Wuhan, he, too, was diagnosed with COVID-19 and began treatment under isolation until he was discharged from the hospital on January 30.

On Feb. 1, a reporter from the China Youth Daily interviewed him about some issues of public concern.

1. When were you sent to work in Wuhan? What is the role of an expert? What was the situation in Wuhan at that time?

Wang Guangfa: I arrived in Wuhan on the evening of the 8th (January) and started working on the 9th. There was nothing unusual on the street, but I was struck by the patient because it was really SARS-like and very distinctive. But for "human-to-human" , our expert group is always in a state of confusion.

I'm the second group of experts to Wuhan. We split up into groups. Different tasks. I am in the medical treatment group, focusing on the treatment of patients, very busy every day, working until three or four o'clock in the morning is also there. Prevention and control need multi-disciplinary cooperation, the central and local coordination, a division of Labor.

(in Wuhan) these 8 days, the Wuhan Street scene has not changed, everybody should do what. I suspect that was a period of latent development of the epidemic, and from what I can see now there may have been community infection.

In fact, we have been keeping a high degree of vigilance, just suffer from at that time, really not much information. We should speak of science, and we should not send out wrong information without foundation.

One hospital recorded a 17% increase in pneumonia cases in December

2. When did you judge that the epidemic was more serious?

Wang Guangfa: When I returned to Beijing on January 16, I had a very clear judgment that the epidemic might be quite serious. Mainly based on the (Wuhan) fever clinic situation. As soon as they arrived in Beijing, the Group of experts met. I didn't have a fever at the time, and I didn't know of any medical staff infection or human-to-human transmission.

I saw a lot of fever clinic patients, some patients lung CT scan, is very typical of COVID-19 pneumonia. This means that the hospital was able to cope with a large number of such patients who were crowded in the hospital. Here's what we know from January 14th and 15th. So we also suggest to some units, must be prepared, in advance, can not let the patient be silted up in the fever clinic. Some hospitals called me two days ago and said that thanks to your suggestion, our hospital received patients in isolation ward in time and there was no case of staff infection.

In addition, I was also informed that the incidence of pneumonia in a hospital in December was 17% higher than in the same period last year. It hadn't been announced yet, so it wasn't the impact of the announcement. I mentioned at the time that it was a big deal and that we were focusing on the seafood market [ in south China in Wuhan ] , but why is there so much more pneumonia? Moreover, some of the cases we have seen have nothing to do with the south China Seafood Market, nothing at all. This is a strong indication that the outbreak may have occurred much earlier.

I read that Thailand screened more than 11,000 travelers from Wuhan and found one patient. Wuhan's population, we give a discount, 20,000 people found 1, the population of 8 million, that should also have 400 cases. But with the number of cases reported at the time being 41(41 before Jan. 16) , the epidemic must have been underestimated. At that time, we raised this issue, the next day I found that the epidemic prevention "wind" a bit changed, we began to pay attention.

From the scientific point of view, we did not say whether there was human transmission, but from the General Law, we should pay attention to strengthen prevention and control. We also remind the public to protect themselves.

Every time I deal with an outbreak, I'm prepared for the possibility of infection

3. When do you think you were infected?

Wang Guangfa: I am an ordinary person, not God, not steel, will not be invulnerable. As front line health care workers, Remember the Titans, we as national experts, have a very important task, we need to understand this disease, this epidemic. We need primary source, we have to go to the patient's bedside, to the fever clinic. I can't read between the lines. I want to see what's really going on.

I still do not know, in the CDC (CDC) published papers, those infected "medical personnel" does not include me, but I have no seafood market exposure, but also infected, proof of positive human-to-human transmission, no doubt.

No one wants to get sick, I am very depressed, but also very helpless, who let me catch up.

I have participated in the prevention and control of the new SARS in Guangdong, as well as the later bird flu and new flu, as well as the plague in Yunnan and most recently the plague in Inner Mongolia. I've been to small outbreaks like measles, pneumonia, and a local flu outbreak. Every time I deal with an outbreak, I'm prepared for the possibility of infection.

I've been through so many outbreaks, and I've gone to the ward to check on patients, to make sure they're not infected. But you can't walk by the river without getting wet? When we go to war, WHO's to say we won't get hurt? There's more exposure, more chance of infection. I'm infected. It's inevitable.

On my second day in Wuhan, I went to see the patient in ICU. I didn't know much about it at the time, and just listening to people wouldn't do. I'd like to see how severe the critical cases are, if there are any special circumstances. After we see the patient, we can deepen our understanding of the disease. I came in just in time to intubate, so I helped them. It was a high-risk exposure, but I was wearing full protection, so I don't think that close contact was the source of my infection.

Later, I went to several hospitals fever clinic, on the one hand to understand the epidemic, on the other hand to help the local fever clinic work well. One of the hospitals, after entering the more chaotic, more patients, the environment is smaller. I later learned that, probably right before and after me, one of the doctors I knew at that hospital was also infected.

I remember being in that hospital and seeing people with the flu, and seeing people who looked like they had COVID-19 pneumonia, and I was wearing an N95 mask and hat and gloves, but no goggles. I would later speculate that the number of patients in the small space, the concentration of the virus is relatively high, combined with the doctor also infected the situation, the health care staff may have to upgrade protection. The group is not equipped with goggles because they are not normally required, but if a large number of patients are admitted, local viral concentrations are high, ventilation is poor and space is small, these conditions combine to make it possible for infection to occur through the MUCOSA. It's just a theory of mine.

The day after I returned to Beijing, I was in a meeting. I felt something was wrong. I felt something strange in my eyes. I took a look at it with my mobile phone camera. My eyes were red. Then there are upper respiratory symptoms, nasal congestion, mild runny nose, sore throat, followed by fever, chills. Because I was in the fever clinic, the first thing I thought about was the flu. Influenza is much more infectious than coronavirus pneumonia, probably the most infectious of all infectious diseases, and more infectious than SARS, but it's not that pathogenic.

I was a clinician with a habit of clinical thought, so I compared my situation with that of the 41 new cases of coronavirus pneumonia I knew at the time. I don't remember breathing in the manual, either, but I sequestered myself for the day. The next day I wore a mask to the hospital emergency room and was tested negative for the flu virus.

Influenza virus detection, sensitivity is very low, can reach 60% sensitivity is good. So I think, negative can not explain the problem, still according to the flu treatment, Take Oseltamivir, systemic symptoms such as muscle aches, headache, body temperature slightly down, but nasal congestion, runny nose still exist. On the fourth day, January 20th, the fever returned in the evening. Anti-flu meds should be effective within 48 hours of onset. At the time, I knew something was wrong. I had to think about the new coronavirus pneumonia.

The first time, I called our hospital, told the relevant leadership, I may be infected, hope to arrange a nucleic acid test. At about 9:30 p.m. , I went to the emergency room to get a throat swab and sputum. That night, I had such a bad headache, I couldn't sleep at all, and I had a high fever. The next day, January 21, the nucleic acid test was positive, and the CT of the lungs showed typical signs of pneumonia. That's how it was diagnosed.

At that time, I was also relatively calm, thinking about the circumstances of the aggravation, even thought about "to see Marxism. " . But I'm a therapist, and I've seen a lot of life and death, and I'm okay with it, so let's treat it.

I have seen countless lung slices, which day not to see a few lung slices? This time I looked at my own lung film, I think in the cases I have seen, should be relatively light, not to rule out the development of heavy. So I focus on the symptoms of coughing and difficulty breathing, but oddly, I don't cough at all, and I don't have difficulty breathing, at the height of my fever. That's when the hospital started making arrangements for me to be transferred to Temple of Earth Hospital, and I just sat there in quarantine, waiting.

In fact, as long as the prevention and control of infectious diseases, as long as contact with patients, infection may occur. Now the medical staff protection condition is much better, still may infect, specially in the epidemic concentration outbreak time, the order is disorderly, the people are busy.

We go to the front line, not because we believe we can't get sick, but because we have to. For example, this trip to Wuhan was assigned to me by Weijian. In this case, the leader made a call to the hospital as if she were going to participate in the country's outbreak control. I never haggle because it's the right thing to do. When I was a child, I was not in good health. My father's friend suggested me to study medicine. My parents did not object. Then someone asked me if I regretted it, and I still felt a sense of accomplishment. The greatest sense of accomplishment is that the patient is cured -- as if she came in on her back and went out on her feet. What a virtue it is to pull someone back from the brink of death.

There was no clear evidence of human-to-human transmission

4. What research have you done in Wuhan? What are the main concerns?

Wang: We were actually on the alert for the outbreak, and the concern was the public concern -- was there a human being in Florida? Is it contagious? But the information we have is relatively limited, from the limited information, we did not see clear evidence of human-to-human transmission at that time.

But we're not limited to just one report, because it's second-hand, mostly from local CDC and HHS reports. We go down to see the patients, too. We're looking at a patient with a signature. And it's different from pneumonia we've seen before, it's similar to SARS, but overall, it's less severe than the cases we experienced during SARS.

When we're clinicians, we're looking at one person at a time, not the other way around. What I need to do is to look at the characteristics of the disease and figure out what the strategy is. Whether the disease is infectious, clinical doctors should also pay attention, but the most important is to rely on the Department of Disease Control and investigation to determine.

You may not know much about these divisions of expertise. There is now more and more evidence of human to human transmission, but there was no evidence at the time, but care in hospitals and fever clinics and pre-screening and triage in clinics have strengthened the protection of medical staff.

At the time, we were given 41 confirmed cases, two of which were clustered. We consulted experts at the CDC, and based on two clusters of cases, we could not conclude that "human-to-human" , which requires an epidemiologist to answer.

Judging human-to-human transmission is a technical job. It is not that there are two people in a family. It is human-to-human transmission. This is a complex scientific concept, reflecting the intensity of infectious diseases, there is a replication number, that is, a patient can pass to several people, it is to go through a series of calculations, this is a quantitative indicator of the intensity of infectious diseases, it is not a matter of any one person being able to say it, it should be a matter of collective judgment.

I would like to emphasize that it is not individuals who judge the epidemic, it is the collective judgment, but the judgment data must be correct. There are gaps in the original data, and even some information is not available at all, leading to errors in judgment.

On the tenth anniversary of SARS, I wrote, you can't keep the lid on. The more you cover, the worse it gets. The public can not hide, the public may panic, but often experience "low-dose stimulus" , the public gradually accepted. There's no way to cover up an outbreak so professionals can't see what's really going on.

"preventable and controllable" is not to say "no prevention and no control" , there is consensus in the expert group

I thought you were worried about my "manageable" comment? So far, we can't say the disease is "uncontrollable" , can we? It's just that we're expensive. That's another thing.

So I think this process is worth summing up, from an expert point of view, there is a step-by-step understanding of the process.

When I say "manageable, " what I really mean is, at any given stage, we should be confident that, after all we've been through, which one hasn't?

In fact, we also put forward a lot of suggestions, not that "can prevent and control" is "not prevent and control" , but the need to strengthen attention. In the panel, there was a consensus.

From the later situation, I think we should reflect, the information conveyed by the experts as complete as possible, we see the information also do not take out of context. See"can prevent controllable", feel good, everything is OK, can prevent what? Everyone's measures are in place, we all pay attention to, in order to be controllable.

For example, "goggles" thing, in fact, I suggest the medical staff, because they stay in that place all day, mucous membrane infection will be more opportunities, did not expect the public to rob, no way, I sent a micro-blog to explain.

Of course, it makes sense. For one thing, some people misunderstand that it is "preventable and controllable. " For another, I am a member of the National Expert Group. People think, "this person should be impervious to poison. How can such a high expert be infected? "

At the time of hospitalization, it was suggested that the new type pneumonia should be classified as a class B infectious disease

5. YOUTH.GOV.HK: You returned from Wuhan to Beijing, until later hospitalized, the whole epidemic has made progress. During this period, in addition to receiving treatment, have you made any recommendations for the prevention and control of the epidemic?

Wang Guangfa: When the country is in trouble, every man is responsible. To See the development of the epidemic, in fact, very anxious, but also trapped in isolation ward. But fortunately, my illness is not serious, although sick, still able to work. I gave the authorities at all levels their own assessment of the epidemic, put forward comments and suggestions, including guidelines for the update, the adoption of important measures. To put forward classified management, multi-sector linkage, adopt different prevention and control strategies for Wuhan, the surrounding areas of Wuhan and other areas, pay close attention to the development of the epidemic around Wuhan, classify the new coronavirus pneumonia as a class B infectious disease, and manage according to Class A, and so on and so forth.

Another example is to limit the flow of people, pay attention to the surrounding areas of Wuhan, do not let these places become the spread of the epidemic out of the channel.

For example, after the Spring Festival, the problem of people returning to Beijing, the need for multi-sectoral linkage. We should not only consider the social operation, but also pay attention to the prevention and control of diseases. In order to prevent and control disease, people do not move at all, this is not realistic, the country still has to run, goods still have to be produced, transported. There's a limit to what you can do. At present, the work in Beijing seems to be relatively solid, although the number of cases is increasing, the situation of prevention and control is relatively stable. One is that the leaders at all levels in Beijing attach importance to it. The other is that Beijing is rich in medical resources, has experience in fighting SARS, and has reserves left over from fighting SARS, such as Xiaotangshan Hospital.

However, do not take it lightly, I am now more worried about some cases of no source, may be community infection, not imported cases. In the early days, it was an input, and this person went somewhere, passed it on, and it became a local case. Three, four generations of indigenous cases, and the virus Kalanchoe Pinnata. If we are not careful, there may be a second Wuhan. Big cities are prone to this.

Mass control is our country's advantage, but in accordance with the law, some people from the field back, do not let people into the house, which is illegal. He's sick. We can call the authorities, put him in isolation. How can you not let someone go home without symptoms? We could do 14 days at home.

In a city like Beijing, where medical resources are concentrated and the epidemic is not too severe, it is safest to isolate and hospitalize any cases found. But in Wuhan, some patients have not yet been fully admitted. Today I wrote a proposal to the relevant departments to study the norms of family segregation in Wuhan.

Leave the patient at home. Somebody's got Ta do something. Who's got Ta do something? How? Under what circumstances does a patient have to be hospitalized? This should play the role of community health care, play referral mechanism, should be well studied. Our Social Governance, a few words quite simple, involves the content is too complicated, is not so easy to do. I hope that the introduction of certain policies, must be carefully considered, do not shoot a brain out of a policy, the last look at the grass-roots level, not the right.

Like Wuhan, the epidemic is more serious, the inpatient capacity is insufficient, the mild illness patient may isolate at home, but must judge accurately, what kind of patient is mild illness.

A big problem right now is diagnosis. The development of the epidemic so far, the need for a confirmed nucleic acid testing, diagnostic capacity is not enough. To judge whether the patient can be discharged, it must be negative for two nucleic acid tests, one day apart, the test can not be detected, and the patient dare not discharge, affecting the efficiency. In addition, false positive, false negative, will bring great problems.

I have been pushing the rapid diagnosis method repeatedly with the relevant departments these days. But before these technologies go into clinical practice, they need to be evaluated scientifically, to develop products, to conduct clinical research.

Rapid screening, once available, would greatly improve the dilemma of epidemic prevention and control. Maybe soon. I'm pushing.

In addition, I am very concerned about the treatment of serious and critical patients, so we have a program specifically aimed at the serious patients, reducing the mortality rate.

We need to stick together

6. What is your assessment of the current outbreak?

Wang Guangfa: I haven't analyzed the data particularly carefully, but when I look at the epidemic situation in Hubei and the whole country, the rate of increase in confirmed cases seems to be declining. I think this is a good trend, indicating that our early work may be effective. In fact, according to the experience left by SARS at that time, the patient received it, the source of infection was controlled, the infectious disease was controlled.

I now estimate that this outbreak may have occurred much earlier. By the time we were alerted, there were actually a lot of patients. This is something to be summed up in the future.

At the moment, as long as we put in place measures, each of us is responsible, do a good job, put the patients in, put the patients in isolation, I believe the epidemic will continue. It's GonNa take a little longer. It's promising, but it's tough.

Kill. Since the outbreak of the disease, a number of related papers have been published by Chinese scholars, such as a study published online in the Lancet on January 24 by Professor Cao Bin, a corresponding author, have you read the paper, the early transmission dynamics of COVID-19 pneumonia in Wuhan, China, published Jan. 29 in the Journal The New England Journal of Medicine?

Wang Guangfa: Professor Cao Bin flagged me down, showed me the paper and signed it. But I wasn't the lead author on the paper, and I wasn't involved in the data collection from start to finish. There are many cases for the initial point of view, now there are many cases, the paper some points may not be correct.

I don't know about the CDC paper, more than 400 cases, I don't even know if I'm included. I don't know how that paper came out. But I think, in one respect, it is important to sum up the experience. The first of all the epidemic prevention and control, should be practical work, I do not object to writing papers, the important thing is, I hope that before the publication of the paper, there is a full share of experts, so as to facilitate the prevention and control of disease. It takes a lot of information to make a comprehensive diagnosis, and it's necessary that this information be presented before the paper is published.

What suggestions do you have for the public?

Grab Mask, disinfectant and Shuanghuanglian oral liquid, these messages can be said to emerge one after another. You don't have to be so nervous. What kind of mask do you wear when you're at home or in a country park and you don't have close contact with people? In the open air, keep a distance, say, over 1.5 meters, and don't wear a mask. Droplet transmission will not fly too far, close contact transmission, as long as a good grasp, timely wear masks, is not particularly easy to spread.

Of course, if you go to the hospital, you have to be alert. It's a different environment. As long as you don't have someone spitting on you, you don't have to go out for a walk or go to the hospital and come back with a different coat. I don't have that many jackets myself.

Disease Prevention and control should be scientific, rational, some excessive meaningless measures, there is no need. Now a few words on the keyboard, and suddenly the whole world knows. Information travels fast and has many benefits, but so does the spread of rumors.

I recommend that you take a look at WHO's website, there is a Chinese version, some suggestions to the public, written is quite good. CDC website, for the public and professionals have some advice, the language is also relatively simple, there is no complex reason. To help us figure out what's going on.

Having a disease gives me a more direct understanding of the disease. Less debate, more action. If the epidemic doesn't get under control, we'll all get hurt. It is imperative that we all take action to strictly guard against, scientifically and legally prevent and control. It doesn't make any sense for disease control to just sit around all day doing nothing. So I think at this stage, the most important thing may not be the issue of accountability, the most important thing is that we should unite to control the epidemic, and then we can learn from experience, learn lessons, and improve our work in a timely manner. (Yang Hai, a reporter for CYP. CN, contributed to this report.)
